q01.question:
As discussed in class, working with low-level functions and system calls can be tricky because unlike most normal functions, they can fail. For each of the following scenarios involving moveit, identify which low-level function or system call (used in moveit) would fail:

  1. User has reached their limit of file descriptors. ____
  2. User has reach their limit of processes. ____
  3. User has their EDITOR set to vscode but it does not exist on the system. ____
  4. User does not have permission to write to a destination path. ____

q02.question:
In moveit, you should have used execlp in the edit_files function. Given the following code:

execlp("vscode", "editor", "tmp.file", NULL);

Which of the following statements regarding are true (select all that apply)?

responses.path_vscode: The path to the program to load into memory is vscode.
responses.arg0_vscode: The argv[0] of the process will be vscode.
responses.path_editor: The path to the program to load into memory is editor.
responses.arg0_editor: The argv[0] of the process will be editor.

q03.question: An eager student proposes changing timeit such that the child process sets an alarm before calling execvp so that it can kill itself if the signal handler is invoked. Would this work?

responses.nope_1: Nope, only a parent process can set an <tt>alarm</tt>.
responses.nope_3: Nope, <tt>execvp</tt> loads new code so the <tt>alarm</tt> handler is removed.

q04.question: A malicious student proposes changing timeit such that the child process changes the ChildPid global variable before calling execvp in order to prevent the parent from killing the child process. Would this work?

responses.nope_1: Nope, only a parent process can change global variables.
responses.nope_2: Nope, a process cannot modify global variables.
responses.nope_3: Nope, the parent and child have separate address spaces.

q05.question: A concerned student proposes changing timeit such that the parent process sends SIGSTOP to the child process when alarm handler is invoked. Would this work?

responses.nope_1: Nope, because the child process can ignore SIGSTOP.
responses.nope_2: Nope, because only the kernel can use this signal.
responses.nope_3: Nope, because this only suspends the process and does not terminate it.

q06.question:
A clever student proposes changing timeit such parse_options simply returns a pointer to the first command line option in argv that is not a flag:

int argind = 1;

while (argind < argc && strlen(argv[argind]) > 1 && argv[argind][0] == '-') {
    char *arg = argv[argind++];
    ...
}

...

return &argv[argind];

Would this work?

responses.nope_0: Nope, you cannot use <tt>&</tt> on an element in an array.
responses.nope_1: Nope, execvp requires the vector to be on the heap.
